facts.text: The property in dispute originally belonged to Ramchandra.

anchor.surface_text: The property in dispute originally belonged to one Ramchandra who died sonless in the year 1903.

facts.text: Ramchandra died sonless in the year 1903.

anchor.surface_text: He was survived by his mother, Sheokori, his widow, Mst. Badni, and his two daughters,.

facts.text: Ramchandra was survived by his mother Sheokori, his widow Mst. Badni, and his two daughters Bhuri and Laxmi.

anchor.surface_text: He was survived by his mother, Sheokori, his widow, Mst. Badni, and his two daughters,. Bhuri and Laxmi.

facts.text: Ramchandra made an oral will under which he bequeathed the property in dispute to his daughter Laxmi.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that he made an oral will under which he bequeathed the property in dispute to his daughter, Laxmi.

facts.text: On 6th September 1906, Mst. Sheokori and Mst. Badni executed and registered a deed of gift of the property in dispute in favour of Mst. Laxmi.

anchor.surface_text: On the 6th September, 1906, Mst. Sheokori and Mst. Badni, purporting to act in accordance with the directions of the oral will, executed and registered a deed of gift of the property in dispute in favour of Mst. Laxmi.

facts.text: Bhuri, the second daughter, died in the year 1907.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly Ramchandras estate companyld number devolve on her. Bhuri, the second daughter, died in the year 1907, while Mst. Badni, the widow., died in the year 1927.

facts.text: Mst. Badni died in the year 1927.

anchor.surface_text: Bhuri, the second daughter, died in the year 1907, while Mst. Badni, the widow., died in the year 1927.

facts.text: Mst. Laxmi remained in possession of the property till her death in the year 1928.

anchor.surface_text: Mst. Laxmi remained in possession of the property till her death in the year 1928.

facts.text: Balabux, husband of Laxmi, mortgaged the house to defendant appellant Nathoo Lal on 5th July 1930.

anchor.surface_text: After her death Balabux, her husband, on the 5th of July, 1930, claiming as heir to her mortgaged the house in dispute to the defendant appellant Nathoo Lal

facts.text: Balabux sold the house to Nathoo Lal on 5th October 1933 and put him into possession.

anchor.surface_text: and later on the 5th of October, 1933, he sold it to him and put him into possession of it and since then he is in possession.

facts.text: Nathoo Lal has been in possession since 5th October 1933.

anchor.surface_text: and put him into possession of it and since then he is in possession.

facts.text: Plaintiff, son of Mst. Bhuri, filed suit for possession on 4th October 1945 in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th October, 1945, that is one day before the expiry of the period of 12 years from the date of the defendants entry into possession of the house, the plaintiff, son of Mst. Bhuri, sister of Mst. Laxmi, claiming as an heir to her estate, filed this suit in forma pauperis for possession of the house.

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged he was in possession till 24th August 1933 through tenant, then locked it and went to Harmara, knew on 27th September 1944 that appellant took possession.

anchor.surface_text: He alleged that he was in possession of the house till the 24th of August, 1933, through his tenant, that after it was vacated by the tenant he locked it and went away to his native village Harmara and that on the 27th of September, 1944, he came to know that the house had been taken possession of by the appellant during his absence.

facts.text: Plaintiff contended Balabux had no right to mortgage or sell, Laxmi had only limited estate.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended by him that Balabux had numberright either to mortgage or sell the house and that Laxmi was number the absolute owner of the property but had only a limited estate in it, and on her death he was entitled to possession of it.

facts.text: Civil Judge Jaipur City decreed dismissal of suit on 23rd August 1947.

facts.text: High Court of former Jaipur State decreed plaintiff's appeal on 3rd March 1949 in Second Appeal No. 187 of Samvat 2004.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th of August, 1947, the suit was dismissed by the Civil Judge, who held that Mst. Laxmi became the absolute owner of the property, and the plaintiff therefore had numbertitle to claim possession of it after her death, Balabux being her stridhan heir.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court on review partially allowed on 5th April 1950, amended decree for payment of Rs. 4000 for improvements.

anchor.surface_text: and the review was heard by the Rajasthan High Court as successor to the Jaipur High Court under the High Courts Ordinance and was partially allowed on the 5th of April, 1950, and the decree was accordingly amended and it was provided therein that the plaintiff shall number be entitled to possession of the house except on payment of Rs. 4,000 to the defendant as companyts of improvements and repairs.

facts.text: Supreme Court Civil Appeal No. 59 of 1953 by leave under Article 133(1)(c).

facts.text: Plaintiff admitted Ramchandra made oral will in favour of Laxmi.

anchor.surface_text: That Ramchandra bequeathed the suit property and did number gift it to his daughter Laxmi is a fact which cannot be questioned at this stage. It was admitted by the plaintiff himself in the witness box.

facts.text: Courts below held suit within limitation, plaintiff in possession even during Laxmi's lifetime and continued after.

anchor.surface_text: The three Courts below have unanimously held that on the evidence it was established that after the death of Laxmi plaintiff companytinued in possession of the house and the suit was within limitation.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Laxmi got absolute estate under oral will.

anchor.surface_text: Laxmi therefore became the absolute owner of the property under the terms of the oral will of her father and the plaintiff is numberheir to the property which under the law devolved on Laxmis husband who had full right to alienate it.

facts.text: Trial court held Laxmi absolute owner, Balabux stridhan heir.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th of August, 1947, the suit was dismissed by the Civil Judge, who held that Mst. Laxmi became the absolute owner of the property, and the plaintiff therefore had numbertitle to claim possession of it after her death, Balabux being her stridhan heir.

facts.text: District Judge held widow executed deed as execution of oral will, Laxmi got absolute estate.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, this decision was affirmed by the District Judge. He expressed the opinion that the widow in executing the deed of gift was only acting as an execution of the oral will made by Ramchandra at his deathbed and that Laxmi got under this will an absolute estate in the suit property.

arguments.claim: The appeal is not maintainable because the original decree of the Jaipur High Court in 1949 was final under Jaipur CPC and the review only modified on improvements without reopening the merits

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent raised a preliminary objection as to the maintainability of the appeal. He contended that according to the Code of Civil Procedure of the Jaipur State the decision of the Jaipur High Court had become final as no appeal lay from it and hence this appeal was incompetent. It was argued that the proceedings in the suit decided in 1945 had concluded by the decision of the High Court given in 1949, and the review judgment which modified the decree in regard to improvements, could not entitle the appellant to reopen the decision of the High Court of Jaipur given in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Bakshi Tek Chand for the appellant contended that the Courts below were in error in holding that the plaintiffs suit was within limitation. He urged that in order to bring the suit within limitation the plaintiff in paragraph 5 of the plaint alleged that after the death of Laxmi he kept tenants in the house, realised the rent and enjoyed it and that the last tenant vacated on the 24th August, 1933, and thereafter he went to his native place after locking the house, but that this allegation had not been made good by him, and as there was no evidence that he locked the house, it should be held that plaintiffs possession discontinued with effect from the 24th August, 1933, and hence his suit

arguments.claim: Ramchandra intended gift not will; unable to perfect gift on deathbed so property devolved to widow who gifted limited estate to Laxmi

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand raised two contentions. He urged in the first instance that it seems that the intention of Ramchandra was to make a gift of the suit property in favour of Laxmi but he was unable to perfect the gift by executing a registered deed, being on his deathbed and in that situation the property devolved on his widow by inheritance and it only came to Laxmi under the widows gift and under it she could not get a larger interest than what the widow herself possessed, namely, a limited life estate, which terminated on her death.

holdings.text: The only operative decree in the suit which finally and conclusively determines the rights of the parties is the decree passed on the 5th of April, 1950, by the Rajasthan High Court and that having been passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India, the provisions of article 133 are attracted to it and it is appealable to this Court provided the requirements of that article are fulfilled. The Code of Civil Procedure of the Jaipur State could not determine the jurisdiction of this Court and has no relevancy to the maintainability of the appeal. The requirements of article 133 having been fulfilled, this appeal is clearly competent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this objection is number well founded. The only operative decree in the suit which finally and conclusively determines the rights of the parties is the decree passed on the 5th of April, 1950, by the Rajasthan High Court and that having been passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India, the provisions of article 133 are attracted to it and it is appealable to this Court provided the requirements of that article are fulfilled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review decree of 1950 post-Constitution is operative and appealable under Art 133; Jaipur CPC irrelevant to SC jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The High Court was fully justified in granting the certificate under Article 133(1)(c) as property value exceeded Rs 20,000 and substantial question of law involved.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel then contended that the High Court was in error in granting the certificate in this case. We are unable to agree. An inquiry was made into the valuation of the property and it was reported that its value was Rs. 20,000 or that the decision affected property of the value of above Rs. 20,000.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valuation threshold met; substantial question on estate to Hindu female.

holdings.text: Plaintiff's suit is within limitation as lower courts unanimously found continued possession post-Laxmi's death till 1933 dispossession; presumption of continuity applies, no grounds to interfere.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the Courts below that the plaintiff was in possession of this house even during the lifetime of Laxmi and continued in possession thereafter. Even if the tenant vacated the house on the 24th August, 1933, and the plaintiff did not lock it, his possession would be presumed to continue till he was dispossessed by some one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts lower courts' concurrent findings; law presumes possession continuity until actual dispossession.

holdings.text: Ramchandra bequeathed the property by oral will to Laxmi, not gift; confirmed by plaintiff's admission and gift deed recitals executed in fulfillment by mother and widow as per directions.

anchor.surface_text: That Ramchandra bequeathed the suit property and did number gift it to his daughter Laxmi is a fact which cannot be questioned at this stage. It was admitted by the plaintiff himself in the witness box. This is what he said - Ramchandra had made a will in favour of Mst. Laxmi and in that connection my maternal grandmother and maternal great grandmother got the gift deed registered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff's admission binds; gift deed recitals explicitly reference oral will and directions to register.

holdings.text: The two executants were not conferring their own title but merely giving effect to the oral will as executors; Laxmi became absolute owner under oral will terms, devolving to husband with full alienation rights.

anchor.surface_text: The scribe, it seems, did number in appropriate language express the directions of the two widows and his ideas of the legal situation were somewhat confused but there can be numbermanner of doubt that the two executants were number conferring themselves any title which they had in the property on Laxmi but were merely giving effect to the oral will as executors and were putting the legatee in possession of the bequeathed property in this manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gift deed recitals show acting per will directions; Sheokori (no title) joined confirms not own transfer.

holdings.text: Laxmi became the absolute owner of the property under the terms of the oral will of her father and the plaintiff is not heir to the property which under the law devolved on Laxmi's husband who had full right to alienate it.

anchor.surface_text: Laxmi therefore became the absolute owner of the property under the terms of the oral will of her father and the plaintiff is numberheir to the property which under the law devolved on Laxmis husband who had full right to alienate it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will intent to confer full title as testator had; gift deed recitals ('deal in any way you like') confirm absolute.

holdings.text: No presumption that grant/will to Hindu female confers limited estate absent express words; general Hindu law/TPA s8 rule: estate without limitation words carries inheritance estate unless restricted.

anchor.surface_text: This is the general principle of law which is recognized and embodied in section 8 of the Transfer of Property Act and unless it is shown that under Hindu Law a gift to a female means a limited gift or carries with it the restrictions or disabilities similar to those that exist in a widows estate, there is no justification for departing from this principle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overrules prior view; follows recent SC (Ram Gopal) and JC precedents; no Hindu law distinction for females.

holdings.text: The learned Judges of the High Court were therefore clearly wrong in law in holding that the will having been made by the father in favour of his daughter, it should be presumed that he intended to give her a limited life estate.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court were therefore clearly wrong in law in holding that the will having been made by the father in favour of his daughter, it should be presumed that he intended to give her a limited life estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred applying outdated presumption; words of amplitude suffice for absolute estate.

precedents.cited_proposition: bequest to a daughter-in-law passed a limited estate and gift of immovable property to a woman could not confer absolute estate unless express terms for heritable estate or power of alienation
precedents.cited_holding: a bequest to a daughter-in-law passed a limited estate

anchor.surface_text: Nagammal v. Subbalakshmi Ammal 2

precedents.cited_proposition: no presumption one way or the other between male and female donees and gift to woman is absolute if words sufficient for male

anchor.surface_text: Ram Gopal Nand Lal 3

precedents.cited_proposition: no warrant for proposition that grant to Hindu female does not confer absolute or alienable interest unless expressly conferred; enough if words convey full ownership
precedents.cited_holding: It may be taken to be quite settled that there is no warrant for the proposition of law that when a grant of an immovable property is made to a Hindu female, she does not get an absolute or alienable interest in such property, unless such power is expressly conferred upon her.

precedents.cited_proposition: estate given to a man without express words of inheritance carries estate of inheritance by Hindu Law absent conflicting context
precedents.cited_holding: if an estate were given to a man without express words of inheritance, it would, in the absence of a conflicting context, carry, by Hindu Law, an estate of inheritance

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this objection is number well founded. The only operative decree in the suit which finally and conclusively determines the rights of the parties is the decree passed on the 5th of April, 1950, by the Rajasthan High Court and that having been passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India, the provisions of article 133 are attracted to it and it is appealable to this Court provided the requirements of that article are fulfilled.
For the reasons given above we allow the appeal, set aside the decree of the High Court decreeing the plaintiffs suit and restore the decree of the trial Court dismissing the
clearly companypetent. The learned companynsel then companytended that the High Court was in error in granting the certificate in this case. We are un

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel then contended that the High Court was in error in granting the certificate in this case. We are unable to agree. An inquiry was made into the valuation of the property and it was reported that its value was Rs. 20,000 or that the decision affected property of the value of above Rs. 20,000.
For the reasons given above we allow the appeal, set aside the decree of the High Court decreeing the plaintiffs suit and restore the decree of the trial Court dismissing the

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the Courts below that the plaintiff was in possession of this house even during the lifetime of Laxmi and continued in possession thereafter.
